Cu-ZnO based catalysts are widely used for CO2 hydrogenation, but the CH3OH selectivity still needs to be improved. In this paper, dual-site Cu-ZnO/Cu@Si catalysts with Cu-O-Si structure and Cu-ZnO interface were prepared, and the 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si sample exhibits optimal catalytic performance with the methanol selectivity and space-time yield of 70.6 % and 6.7 mmolMeOH·gcat −1·h −1 at 260 °C and 3 MPa, far exceeding those of the conventional Cu-ZnO/SiO2 (7.0 % for methanol selectivity and 1.22 mmolMeOH·gcat −1·h −1 for STY MeOH). The Cu-O-Si active site in Cu@Si is beneficial to the methanol synthesis and DFT calculations demonstrate the hydrogenation process follows the formate pathway. The Cu-ZnO interface can further convert CO generated at the Cu-O-Si active site to methanol. This synergistic effect is the main reason for the good catalytic performance of the dual-site samples. In-situ DRIFTS results also give evidence that *HCOO can be effectively hydrogenated to form *CH3O and the less gaseous CO exists on 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si. Graphical abstract CO2 can be hydrogenated to form CH3OH and CO at the Cu-O-Si active site, and CO can be further converted into methanol at the Cu-ZnO interface. Image, graphical abstract Keywords Dual-site catalysts Cu-O-Si structure Cu-ZnO interface Methanol selectivity Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the past 60 years, the excessive combustion of coal, oil, and natural gas by human beings has generated a large amount of CO2 (one of the main components of greenhouse gasses), and this leads to many environmental issues [1–3]. In order to maintain long-term social development, effective measures must be taken to solve this problem. The carbon capture and utilization (CCU) can not only reduce greenhouse gas emissions but also convert CO2 into valuable chemicals [4,5]. Therefore, researchers all over the world are paying attention to this technology and the catalytic conversion of CO2. Currently, the products are diverse, including carbon monoxide [6], methanol [7], ethanol [8], methane [9], formic acid [3], dimethyl ether [10], aromatics [11], and olefins [12], etc. Among them, methanol is a good candidate for storing hydrogen, due to its feature of high energy density, easy storage and transportation [13], and this is also the foundation of the “methanol economy”. What's more, methanol can also be used as a raw material to prepare various platform chemicals. Thus, the hydrogenation of CO2 to CH3OH has a rather high practical value. Heterogeneous catalysts for methanol synthesis include Cu-based and In-based [14,15] materials, Ni-Ga intermetallic compounds [16,17], Zn-Zr solid solutions [18,19], MOFs [20], and carbides [21], etc. Wherein, Cu-based catalysts are the most extensively investigated because they have great potential for industrial application, especially for the Cu-ZnO. Kattel et al. [22] constructed ZnCu and ZnO/Cu models to determine the active sites for methanol synthesis. XPS characterization, DFT calculation, KMC simulation, and experimental results all demonstrated that ZnCu was oxidized during the reaction process, and Zn became ZnO. When the coverage of ZnO was the same as that of ZnO/Cu, ZnCu could reach the catalytic activity of ZnO/Cu. So, they drew a conclusion that the interface between Cu and ZnO was of great importance to obtain methanol. Qi et al. [23] prepared a series of Cu/ZnO/Y2O3 catalysts by a citric acid coordination-assisted method to explore the effect of yttria doping. Through the results of various characterizations, they found the Y-doping could increase the dispersion of Cu species, CO2 adsorption sites and Cu-ZnO interface. Cui et al. [24] encapsulated ultrasmall Cu/ZnOx particles (∼ 2 nm) into zeolite and the obtained optimal Cu/ZnOx (1.38) @Na-ZSM-5 catalyst had a good catalytic activity with the STY MeOH of 44.88 gMeOH·gcat −1·h −1. They reported that the synergy effect between the zeolitic framework and the Cu/ZnOx played an essential role in the hydrogenation process. Guo et al. [25] prepared Cu-ZnO/Al2O3, Cu-ZnO/Al2O3−MgO, and Cu-ZnO/MgO to explore the influence of surface basicity on hydrogenation performance. They found that MgO could effectively increase the surface basicity, which not only enhanced the adsorption of CO2 and CO but also inhibited the CH3OH decomposition. From a single solid precursor, Shao et al. [26] loaded the Cu-ZnO onto the siliceous nanowire networks (SNN). The obtained Cu-Zn-Si catalyst by this newly developed strategy had several advantages: the desired synergy could be achieved between Cu and ZnO because of SMSI; the SNN could limit the growth of the highly dispersed Cu nanoparticles in the hydrogenation process; the macroporous structure provided high accessibility. Despite extensive research, methanol selectivity still needs to be improved due to the existence of the reverse water-gas shift (RWGS) reaction, which is the main competitive process in methanol synthesis, especially at high temperatures. If the CO produced by RWGS can be further utilized (CO + 2H2 → CH3OH, ΔH298K = -90.6 kJ·mol−1), this will greatly improve the catalytic activity and methanol selectivity. Recently, inert SiO2 has also been developed as a support. Wang et al. [27] stated that the Cu/SiO2 catalyst synthesized by an ammonia-evaporation (AE) method was highly efficient for CO2 hydrogenation. At 320 °C and 3 MPa, the CO2 conversion of the Cu/SiO2-AE could reach 28 %, and the CH3OH selectivity (21.3 %) was also higher than the equilibrium value (6.6 %). Through the flame spray pyrolysis (FSP), Yu et al. [13] got a Cu/SiO2 catalyst with catalytic performance comparable to Cu/ZrO2. The unique shattuckite-like precursor with Cu−O−Si structure in the preparation process enriched the FSP-Cu/SiO2 catalyst with abundant Cu+, which stabilized *CO and boosted its further hydrogenation to CH3OH (the RWGS + COHydro pathway). However, the CO selectivity is still about 50 % at the CO2 conversion of 8 %, and the equipment used for the FSP technology is very expensive. What's more, the reason for the promotion of Cu-O-Si still needs to be further studied, because other researchers had a different opinion that Cu+ was a stabilizer for CH3O* species [28,29], thus boosting the CH3OH formation. In addition to CO2 hydrogenation, the promotion effect of SiO2 can also be observed in other reactions [30,31]. For example, Zhu et al. said that the Cu-O-Si bonds formed in the calcination process would supply adequate active Cu0 and Cuδ+sites in the reduction procedure, facilitating the hydrogenolysis of 5-hydroxymethylfurfural to 2,5-dimethylfuran. Inspired by what was discussed above, we prepared a dual-site Cu-ZnO/Cu@Si catalyst, which contains Cu-O-Si structure and Cu-ZnO interface. The CO produced at Cu-O-Si active sites can be further converted to CH3OH at the Cu-ZnO interface, and this synergistic effect enables them to exhibit good catalytic activity and methanol selectivity. Cu@Si, Cu/SiO2, and Cu-ZnO/SiO2 were also prepared for comparison. Various characterization techniques and DFT calculations were used to analyze the catalyst structure and reaction mechanism, establishing a good structure-activity relationship. We believe that this manuscript will provide useful suggestions for researchers to design high-performance catalysts. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation 2.1.1 Synthesis of Cu@XSi The Cu@XSi (X was the molar ratio of Si to Cu) catalysts were obtained through the in-situ hydrolysis of tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) in the presence of Cu2+and NH3·H2O, followed by calcination and reduction. The Cu@12Si was chosen as an example to describe the typical preparation process: 1.208 g (5 mmol) of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O was dissolved in the mixture of 75 ml deionized water and 25 ml absolute ethanol, and then 12.50 g (60 mmol) of TEOS was added into the above solution. After stirring for 30 min, 5 ml NH3·H2O was added to the mixed liquid and stirred for another 8 h. Next, the precipitate was filtered out, washed with deionized water several times, and dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight. Finally, the obtained powder was calcined in the muffle furnace at 350 °C for 4 h with a heating rate of 5 °C/min and then reduced in the 10 vol. % H2/N2 atmosphere at 300 °C for 2 h. The other Cu@XSi catalysts were synthesized by the same method except that the mass of TEOS added was different. 2.1.2 Preparation of yCu-ZnO/Cu@12Si The impregnation method was used to synthesize the yCu-ZnO/Cu@12Si catalysts and y was the weight percentage of Cu and ZnO to Cu@12Si (the mass ratio of loaded Cu and ZnO was fixed at 3:2). A certain amount of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and Zn(NO3)2·6H2O were added to 20 ml deionized water, and then 1 g of Cu@12Si was added and stirred for 8 h. Afterwards, the water was evaporated and the remaining solid was dried overnight at 80 °C. Finally, the obtained powder was calcined in the muffle furnace at 350 °C for 4 h and then reduced in the 10 vol. % H2/N2 at 300 °C for 2 h. More details were listed in Table S1. 2.1.3 Synthesis of Cu/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/SiO2 The Cu/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/SiO2 catalysts with commercial SiO2 as support were also prepared through the impregnation method. For the Cu-ZnO/SiO2, 0.575 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and 0.157 g of Zn(NO3)2·6H2O were added to 20 ml deionized water, and then 1 g of SiO2 was added and stirred for 8 h. The next steps are identical to the yCu-ZnO/Cu@12Si. The synthesis procedure for Cu/SiO2 catalyst was the same as Cu-ZnO/SiO2 except that 0.32 g of Cu(NO3)2·3H2O and no zinc salt was added. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The Fourier-transform IR (FT-IR) spectra of the calcined catalysts were collected on a Nicolet 5700 spectrometer. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns of the reduced samples were obtained on a Rigaku Ultima IV X-ray diffractometer equipped with a CuKα source, and the voltage and current are 40 kV and 40 mA. The diffraction data were recorded in a 2θ range of 20° to 60° with a step size of 0.02° The textural properties of the calcined catalysts were measured on the Micromeritics ASAP 2460 apparatus by N2 adsorption-desorption at −196 °C. Prior to the analysis, all the samples were degassed at 250 °C for 3 h. Barret-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) and the Brunauer-Emmet-Teller (BET) methods were used to calculate the pore structure and specific surface areas. The Electron Paramagnetic Resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker EMX spectrometer with a power of 6.3 mW and a modulation amplitude and frequency of 3 G and 100 kHz, respectively. The reduction behavior of the catalysts was examined by the H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR) experiment on a chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics AutoChem1 II 2920). After being purged by pure argon, the catalyst was heated to 500 °C in a 10 vol. % H2/Ar mixture (30 mL/min). The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra were collected on the Thermo Scientific K-Alpha instrument equipped with Al Kα X-ray as the radiation source (1486.6 eV). The C1s Peak (284.8 eV) was used to calibrate the banding energy (BE) of all peaks. Transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning TEM (STEM), and high-resolution TEM (HR-TEM) images of the reduced catalysts were obtained on a Talos F200X microscope with an acceleration voltage of 200 kV and a resolution of 0.14 nm. In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) was carried out on a Thermo Fisher Nicolet iS50 spectrometer equipped with an MCT detector cooled by liquid nitrogen. Before the measurement, the sample was reduced at 300 °C for 2 h with 10 vol. % H2/Ar mixture at a speed of 30 ml/min. After the system was cooled to 260 °C, the gas flow was changed to a mixture of 25 vol. % CO2/H2, and the spectra were recorded at different times. 2.3 DFT calculations The DMol3 code of the Materials Studio software was employed to complete all the calculations [32,33]. A Cu cluster with four atoms loaded on the SiO2 (110) surface (Cu4/SiO2) was established to simulate the Cu-O-Si structure, and the computational details were described in supporting information. 2.4 Catalyst testing The CO2 hydrogenation was performed in a stainless-steel fixed-bed reactor at 220–280 °C and 3 MPa. In a typical process, 0.2 g of sieved 20–40 mesh calcined catalyst and 0.5 g of quartz sand were placed in the tubular reactor. Before the hydrogenation, the catalyst was reduced at 300 °C for 2 h with 10 vol. % H2/N2 under atmospheric pressure. After cooling to 100 °C, the reactor was pressured with reaction gas (CO2/H2/N2 = 10/30/10 ml/min) to 3 MPa, and the temperature was increased to the desired value. The effluent products were analyzed by an online gas chromatograph equipped with two detectors (TCD and FID). CO2 conversion (X CO2), CH3OH selectivity (S CH3OH), and CH3OH space-time yield (STY CH3OH) were calculated as follows: (1) X C O 2 ( % ) = [ C O 2 ] i n − [ C O 2 ] o u t [ C O 2 ] i n × 100 (2) S C H 3 O H ( % ) = [ C H 3 O H ] o u t [ C O 2 ] i n − [ C O 2 ] o u t × 100 (3) S T Y C H 3 OH ( m m o l C H 3 O H · h − 1 · g cat − 1 ) = F C O 2 , in · X C O 2 · S C H 3 OH W cat where [CO2]in is the concentration of CO2 in the inlet gas, [CO2]out the concentration of CO2 in the outlet gas, [CH3OH]out the concentration of CH3OH at the outlet of the reactor, F CO2, in the molar flow rate of CO2 at the inlet of the reactor, and W cat the mass of the catalyst. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalytic performance The catalytic testing was conducted at 220–280 °C and 3 MPa, and only CH3OH (CO2 + 3H2 → CH3OH + H2O, ΔH298K = −49.5 kJ·mol−1) and CO (CO2 + H2 → CO + H2O, ΔH298K = 41.2 kJ·mol−1, RWGS reaction) are the carbon-containing products in our results. Cu@XSi catalysts with different Cu/Si ratios were first prepared and used for CO2 hydrogenation, and the results are shown in Fig. S1 and S2. From Cu@4Si to Cu@16Si, the CO2 conversion decreases and methanol selectivity gradually increases. The space-time yield of methanol shows a trend of increasing first and then decreasing with the growth of the Si/Cu ratio. Cu@12Si has the optimal value of 4.0 mmolMeOH·gcat −1·h −1, and thus it is selected to support Cu-ZnO to obtain the dual-site catalysts. From Fig. 1 a, we can see that both the CO2 conversion and CH3OH selectivity are improved after the introduction of Cu-ZnO, and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si has the best performance. In order to exhibit the advantages of dual-site catalysts, Cu/SiO2 with the same Cu content as Cu@12Si, and Cu-ZnO/SiO2 with the same Cu and ZnO content as 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si were also prepared by impregnation method for comparison. (ICP-OES was done to determine the metal contents of the four catalysts, and the results in shown in Table 1 . Cu/SiO2 and Cu@12Si have similar Cu content, which is 8.0 % and 7.9 %. The total amounts of Cu and Zn are also very comparable for Cu-ZnO/SiO2 and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si (12.5 % vs 12.6 % for Cu, 2.8 % vs 2.9 % for Zn)). Therefore, the structures, properties, and catalytic performance of these four catalysts are mainly discussed in this paper. As depicted in Fig. S3, the conversion of CO2 increases with the increasing temperature, but the methanol selectivity shows an opposite trend for all the four samples (Fig. 1b). This is mainly because the side reaction (RWGS) is endothermic and is easier to occur at high temperatures. Compared with Cu/SiO2, Cu@12Si is more conducive for CH3OH synthesis because it has higher CH3OH selectivity and space-time yield (Fig. 1c) under the same reaction conditions. For instance, Cu@12Si behaves the value of 52.8 % and 4.0 mmolMeOH·gcat −1·h −1 at 260 °C, which is 1.61 and 1.31 times higher than the value of Cu/SiO2. The Cu-O-Si structure in Cu@12Si was the main reason for its better methanol formation ability (discussed below). Cu-ZnO/SiO2 has extremely high CO2 conversion and it can achieve 18.1 % at 280 °C, but the CH3OH selectivity is pretty low (only 7.0 %). The dual-site 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si exhibits the highest CH3OH selectivity and space-time yield among the four catalysts at all reaction temperatures. At 260 °C, they are 70.1 % and 6.7 mmolMeOH·gcat −1·h −1, 1.28 and 1.66 times higher than the Cu@12Si. The E a (apparent activation energy) for CH3OH formation on 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si is also smaller than Cu@12Si (12.9 Vs 11.0 kJ·mol−1, Fig. S4). Fig. 1d is the CO2 conversion and CH3OH selectivity during the 24 h time-on-stream over 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si, and both of them are almost unchanged, suggesting its robust feature. Therefore, 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si is a good candidate for CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH. 3.2 Characterizations The textural properties of the four samples were investigated by N2 adsorption–desorption. As shown in Fig. S5, Cu/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/SiO2 have typical IV isotherms with the H2 hysteresis loops, indicating the mesopores are formed due to the gaps between nanoparticles [34]. For Cu@12Si and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si, they have “slit” shape pores because of the H3 type hysteresis loops [35]. Pore size distributions are given in Fig. S6, and Cu/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/SiO2 present one single peak in the 4–12 nm range, but Cu@12Si and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si has two types of pores (3–5 and 15–27 nm). The pore volume, pore size, and BET specific surface area are listed in Table l. Cu/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/SiO2 have a large surface area (351.5 and 286.2 m2/g), but this does not contribute to the generation of methanol. The larger pore size of Cu@12Si and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si is said to be in favor of methanol formation [36]. The FT-IR spectra of the four catalysts are displayed in Fig. 2 a. The absorption peaks located at 470, 800, and 1099 cm−1 are ascribed to the Si-O bond with different vibration forms (symmetry or asymmetry) in SiO2 [37]. The band at 671 cm−1 can be clearly seen on Cu@12Si and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si, and it should be ascribed to the formation of the Cu-O-Si structure [38]. It is also existed in other Cu@XSi and yCu-ZnO/Cu@12Si catalysts, as depicted in Fig. S7. However, this signal is very weak on Cu/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/SiO2, indicating only a small amount of Cu-O-Si content. The difference should be caused by different preparation methods, where in-situ hydrolysis can lead to a stronger interaction between Cu and Si but the impregnation method cannot. The XRD patterns of the reduced catalysts are displayed in Fig. 2b and Fig. S8. The two main diffraction peaks, which are located at 2θ = 43.3 and 50.5°, are attributed to Cu (111) and Cu (200) [35]. They are fairly broad and weak on Cu@4Si and Cu@8Si. For Cu@12Si and Cu@16Si, there are not any peaks of Cu species and only the diffraction signal of SiO2 appears (the broad peak between 20 and 30°). We know that the Cu-O-Si structure is contained in Cu@XSi catalysts, but not all Cu species exist in this form. The Si/Cu ratio is small for Cu@4Si and Cu@8Si, so many Cu species cannot bind with Si to form the Cu-O-Si structure but exist in the form of CuO. These CuO species are easily reduced to Cu nanoparticles, and thus the diffraction peaks are visible. In Cu@12Si and Cu@16Si, most of the Cu species can establish the Cu-O-Si structure, so they are highly stable and dispersed. For Cu/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/SiO2, the intensity of these two peaks is very high, demonstrating they have large Cu nanoparticles. From 5Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si to 15Cu-ZnO/ Cu@12Si, the two peaks gradually become stronger as the increase of Cu loading content. In 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si and 15Cu-ZnO/ Cu@12Si, the signals of ZnO emerge (the tiny and weak peaks at 2θ = 34.5 and 36.4) [25], and this reflects that the successful introduction of Cu-ZnO on the Cu@12Si. The Scherrer equation is used to calculate the average Cu particle size of Cu/SiO2, Cu-ZnO/SiO2, and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si based on the reflection of Cu (111), and their values are 43.4, 51.7 and 34.9 nm, respectively. H2-TPR measurements were conducted to explore the reduction properties of the four catalysts (Fig. 2c). All samples have two peaks below 300 °C, which are due to the reduction of the CuO phase because ZnO and SiO2 cannot be reduced at such a low temperature. The former located at 181–229 °C (peak α) is the reduction of highly dispersed CuO nanoparticles, while the latter at 267–282 °C (peak β) is assigned to the larger or bulk CuO [39]. It should be noted that the intensity of the high-temperature reduction peak is much stronger than the low-temperature one for Cu/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/SiO2. This demonstrates that they mainly contain the larger or bulk CuO, while Cu@12Si and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si have small CuO nanoparticles. Another point should also be paid attention to is that the ratio of the amount of H2 consumption to the theoretical value (based on CuO + H2 → Cu +H2O) is 0.95, 0.98, 0.54, and 0.77 for Cu/SiO2, Cu-ZnO/SiO2, Cu@12Si, and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si, respectively (Fig. 2d). This phenomenon can be reasonably explained that the Cu species in the Cu-O-Si structure of Cu@12Si and Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si are not easy to be reduced. The chemical states of the Cu species of the reduced samples (not used) were investigated by XPS analysis. As depicted in Fig. 3 a, the peaks at 930–938 eV and 950–958 eV are ascribed to Cu 2p3/2 and 2p1/2, respectively [40]. Compared with Cu/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/SiO2, these two peak positions of Cu@12Si and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si shifted by 0.66 eV in the high angle direction. This shift demonstrates that there is a strong interaction between Cu and Si in the Cu@12Si and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si catalysts (the more Cu-O-Si structure) [41]. The small shoulder peak is a signal that the Cu2+ ions exist in all the four catalysts, and their formation should be caused by air oxidation [42]. The Cu LMM Auger spectra were used to further distinguish the valences because the positions of Cu+ and Cu0 are too close. As shown in Fig. 3b, the Auger spectra can be deconvoluted into three parts, and they correspond to Cu2+, Cu+, and Cu0 [43,44]. The Cu+ content is 28.4 and 24.7 % for Cu/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/SiO2, but it increases to 50.1 and 45.9 % for Cu@12Si and Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si (Fig. 3c). This improvement is also attributed to the Cu-Si-O structure. The EPR spectra of Cu-ZnO/SiO2 and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si are displayed in Fig. 3d, and the signal at g = 2.003 is considered as the unpaired electrons trapped in oxygen vacancies of the ZnO surface [45]. It is reported that oxygen vacancies are very important for methanol synthesis because they play the role of adsorption and activation of CO2 [46,47]. However, both of the curves are very burr and the signals are weak, indicating only a very small amount of ZnO in the two catalysts is reduced (The sensitivity of the EPR test is much higher than that of H2-TPR, so no reduction peaks of ZnO can be detected in Fig. 2c). Therefore, the oxygen vacancies should make little contributions to the catalytic performance. Cu nanoparticles on Cu/SiO2 have irregular shapes and are larger than 48 nm, as displayed in Fig. S9. However, the Cu species of Cu@12Si obtained by in-situ hydrolysis are small (2 nm) and have uniform dispersion. Although Cu/SiO2 has a high surface area, the interaction between Cu and SiO2 is very weak. Therefore, after the H2 reduction at 300 °C and 2 h, Cu0 gradually accumulates to form large nanoparticles. The interaction between Cu and Si in Cu@12Si is strong, forming a Cu-O-Si structure, so the dispersion of Cu species is still very good after the reduction. This result is consistent with the XRD and H2-TPR characterizations. Using a conventional formula (d Cu (nm) = 1.04/D Cu), the dispersion of Cu (D Cu) can be estimated as 2.2 % and 52.2 % for Cu/SiO2 and Cu@12Si, respectively. After the introduction of Cu-ZnO, the yCu-ZnO/Cu@12Si catalysts were obtained. From the HR-TEM image (Fig. 4 f), two lattice fringes with the measured spacing of 0.208 and 0.282 nm can be detected, and they are assigned to the (111) plane of metallic Cu and (100) plane of ZnO [40,48]. Between them, the interface is clearly observed (the yellow line). Furthermore, the HAADF-STEM image (Fig. 4a) and the corresponding elemental mappings (Fig. 4b-e) also give evidence that the presence of adequate Cu-ZnO interface because of the highly dispersed Cu and ZnO species. 3.3 Discussion In the FT-IR result, we know that Cu-O-Si structure is more formed in Cu@XSi catalysts than Cu/SiO2 obtained from the impregnation method. The XRD, H2-TPR, XPS, and TEM characterizations demonstrate the Cu species in Cu@12Si are more stable and difficult to reduce than Cu/SiO2, and this difference must be caused by the Cu-O-Si structure. This structure affects the dispersion and valence states of the Cu species, thus having an essential influence on the CH3OH formation. For example, the dispersion of Cu species is higher and more Cu+ is contained in Cu@12Si, so its STY MeOH is 1.31 times higher than Cu/SiO2 at 260 °C. From Cu@4Si to Cu@12Si, the reason why the CH3OH selectivity and space-time yield increase is that the content of Cu-O-Si increases and the Cu0, which is an effective active site to produce CO [49], decreases. The reduced STY MeOH of Cu@16Si should be that the excessive Si blocks the Cu0 and Cu-O-Si sites. As a reflection of the content of Cu-O-Si structure, Cu+ content exhibits a certain linear relationship with STY MeOH (R2 = 0.82, Fig. 5 a), and this gives explicit evidence that the important role of Cu-O-Si structure in synthesizing methanol. Cu/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/SiO2 have higher conversions than Cu@12Si and 10Cu-Zn/Cu@12Si, and the main reason is that RWGS is highly facile to occur at high temperatures. In addition, the large specific surface area should also be a factor. The STY MeOH of Cu/SiO2 is higher than the Cu@12Si at lower reaction temperature but it decreased at higher reaction temperature. This is also caused by the increase of temperature, which makes the CH3OH selectivity of the Cu/SiO2 decrease sharply. For example, the CH3OH selectivity decreases by 61.1 % for Cu/SiO2 from 220 °C to 280 °C, while the value for Cu@12Si is only 33.9 %. DFT calculations were conducted to further understand the promotion effect of Cu-O-Si in the hydrogenation process, and the Cu4/SiO2 (110) structure is established by loading a Cu cluster with four atoms on the SiO2 (110) surface. As shown in Fig. S10, Cu atoms are connected with the O atoms of SiO2 (110) after optimization, which is consistent with the characterization results that the Cu-O-Si structure is formed. On this configuration, CO2 has the adsorption energy of 0.34 eV (one of the O atoms of CO2 can bind with a copper atom, Fig. S11). However, it almost has no interaction with Cu (111) and Cu29 nanoparticles [50,51], which are two representatives of pure Cu (the CO2 molecule reacts with adsorbed H species through the ER mechanism). This indicates that the Cu-O-Si bond can change the adsorption behavior of CO2. From the co-adsorption of CO2 and H (Fig. S12), two intermediates (*HCOO and *COOH) can be obtained and they also represent two different reaction pathways. The first is the formate pathway, and the second is the RWGS+COHydro pathway. In our results, a bidentate configuration with two Cu-O bonds is formed for *HCOO (η2-O, O) and its formation is exothermic (Δ = −0.56 eV) and overcomes an activation energy (E a) of 1.44 eV (Fig. 6 ). For *COOH, the double-linked carbon and oxygen atoms bind with two Cu atoms (η2-C, O). It is less stable and the formation is endothermic (Δ = 0.19 eV, Fig. S12). As a consequence, the formate pathway is preferred over Cu@XSi catalysts. Yang et al. [50] reported that the E a of the rate limiting step for RWGS reaction is smaller than the methanol synthesis over Cu29 nanoparticles, and the reaction rate of the former is approximately two orders of magnitude higher than that of the latter. The produced CO cannot be further converted because the formed *HCO is easily decomposed to *H and *CO before the hydrogenation. As a result, the CO selectivity is extremely high on pure Cu. Cu/SiO2 catalyst mainly exhibits the properties of pure Cu due to the weak interaction between Cu and Si (less Cu-O-Si structure content), so it has poor methanol selectivity. On Cu@12Si, we introduce Cu-ZnO through the impregnation method to get the dual-site yCu-ZnO/Cu@12Si catalysts. In the XRD results, the diffraction peaks of metallic Cu and ZnO appear after the introduction of Cu-ZnO, and their intensity increases with the increasing addition content; the ratio of the amount of H2 consumption to theoretical value is 0.54 and 0.79 (the H2-TPR results) for Cu@12Si and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si, and this enhancement indicates that the reduction of the impregnated CuO, but the Cu species in Cu-O-Si structure are stable and not reduced; the Cu LMM results show that the proportion of Cu+ in Cu@12Si surface is higher than 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si, and the reason for this phenomenon is the same as the reason for the difference in H2-TPR; In the TEM results, the interface between Cu and ZnO can be observed. All these characterization results demonstrate the successful synthesis of the dual-site 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si catalyst, which contains the Cu-ZnO interface and Cu-O-Si structure. As described in 3.1, the dual-site yCu-ZnO/Cu@12Si catalysts have higher CH3OH selectivity and space-time yield than Cu@12Si, indicating the synergy between the Cu-ZnO interface and Cu-O-Si structure. This conclusion is also supported by Fig. 5b, because we can see a decrease of the linearity (compared with Fig. 5a), with 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si having the highest STY MeOH but not the highest Cu+content. It is well-known that Cu-ZnO catalysts are more effective for CO hydrogenation to methanol (CO + H2 → CH3OH, ΔH298K = −90.6 kJ·mol−1) than CO2 hydrogenation, and the industrial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts also catalyze syngas (CO + H2) with a small amount of CO2 to obtain methanol. Therefore, in addition to CO2, the CO produced at Cu-O-Si sites can further hydrogenation to methanol at the Cu-ZnO interface, achieving the effect of a tandem reaction. This synergistic effect greatly improves the space-time yield of methanol, as CO hydrogenation is easier and faster. From 5Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si to 15Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si, the optimal catalytic performance is obtained on 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si, indicating that only an appropriate loading amount can achieve the maximum effect. Although Cu-ZnO interface is included in Cu-ZnO/SiO2, but its content is very small because of the large Cu/Zn mass ratio (about 4.3). For the commercial Cu/ZnO/Al2O3, the mass ratio Cu/Zn is only 2.5. What’ more, the Cu content of Cu-ZnO/SiO2 is bigger than Cu/SiO2 (12.5 % vs 8.0 %). Therefore, Cu-ZnO/SiO2 also mainly exhibits the properties of metallic Cu and has the larger CO selectivity. In situ DRIFTS experiment of the Cu-ZnO/SiO2 and Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si were conducted to observe the change of reaction intermediates and understand the difference of catalytic activity, and the results were exhibited in Fig. 7 . The bands at 1377, 1591, 2116, 2857 and 2930 cm−1 appeared after the introducing of CO2 and H2, and they belong to CO2 δ- (chemisorbed CO2, 1592 cm−1) [52], formate (*HCOO, 1371 and 2857 cm−1) [7,53], gaseous CO (2116 cm−1) [24], and methoxy (*CH3O, 2929 cm−1) [52], respectively. The peak of CO2 δ− is getting stronger and stronger from 5 to 60 min for the two catalysts, indicating that more and more CO2 adsorbed on the catalysts. However, the peak intensity of Cu-ZnO/SiO2 is much higher than Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si, which should be the reason for its high CO2 conversion. *HCOO is obtained from the hydrogenation of the adsorbed CO2. For Cu-ZnO/SiO2, it is increasing gradually throughout the entire testing process but cannot be further hydrogenated, as no other absorption peaks are observed. It is worth noting that the gaseous CO is produced in the first five minutes and then becomes more and more. Therefore, most of the *HCOO species may decompose to CO. For the 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si catalyst, the *CH3O species are emerged (HCOO*→HCOOH*→H2COOH*→CH2O*→CH3O*), which may be related to its higher Cu+ content [28,29] . What's more, due to the further hydrogenation of CO at the Cu-ZnO interface, the peak at 2116 cm−1 appears very late (after 40 min) and is extremely weak. These results perfectly explain why the main product on Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si is methanol and the high CO selectivity of Cu-ZnO/SiO2. 4 Conclusion In summary, dual-site Cu-ZnO/Cu@Si catalysts with Cu-O-Si structure and Cu-ZnO interface were successfully prepared through two consecutive steps, and used for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. In the first step, Cu@XSi catalysts with adequate Cu-O-Si structure were obtained. Combined with various characterizations and experimental results, we demonstrate this structure is in favor of methanol synthesis. DFT calculations were also done to understand the promotion effect and found that CO2 hydrogenation was more inclined to follow the formate pathway. The second is the introduction of the Cu-ZnO interface on Cu@XSi by impregnation method, and this active site could further convert the CO formed in the Cu-O-Si structure to methanol. Therefore, good catalytic performance is obtained for the optimized 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si (70.6 % for methanol selectivity and 6.70 mmolMeOH·gcat −1·h −1 for STY MeOH at 260 °C and 3 MPa). The differences in In-situ DRIFTS results between Cu-ZnO/SiO2 and 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si indicate that the higher methanol selectivity of the latter is due to the further hydrogenation of *HCOO and the less gaseous CO produced. coredata.dc:description: Cu-ZnO based catalysts are widely used for CO2 hydrogenation, but the CH3OH selectivity still needs to be improved. In this paper, dual-site Cu-ZnO/Cu@Si catalysts with Cu-O-Si structure and Cu-ZnO interface were prepared, and the 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si sample exhibits optimal catalytic performance with the methanol selectivity and space-time yield of 70.6 % and 6.7 mmolMeOH·gcat −1·h −1 at 260 °C and 3 MPa, far exceeding those of the conventional Cu-ZnO/SiO2 (7.0 % for methanol selectivity and 1.22 mmolMeOH·gcat −1·h −1 for STY MeOH). The Cu-O-Si active site in Cu@Si is beneficial to the methanol synthesis and DFT calculations demonstrate the hydrogenation process follows the formate pathway. The Cu-ZnO interface can further convert CO generated at the Cu-O-Si active site to methanol. This synergistic effect is the main reason for the good catalytic performance of the dual-site samples. In-situ DRIFTS results also give evidence that *HCOO can be effectively hydrogenated to form *CH3O and the less gaseous CO exists on 10Cu-ZnO/Cu@12Si.
coredata.dc:title: A dual-site Cu-ZnO/Cu@Si catalyst boosts CO2 hydrogenation to CH3OH
